sentence.text: Case 2 is a male infant born at 37 weeks' gestation via normal spontaneous vaginal delivery following an uncomplicated pregnancy to a 33-year-old gravida 4, para 3, aborta 1 mother and a 32-year-old father.
The mother worked in a factory during pregnancy but reported avoidance of chemical exposure.
The baby's birth weight was 7 lb. 3 oz (3267 gm), and at delivery the apparent absence of clavicles and bony calvarium was noted.
There was moderate micrognathia and a high palatal vault.
Upper airway obstruction and retractions occurred when the infant was placed supine, and oxygen supplementation was necessary.
Skull radiographs at 3 days of age showed a lack of parietal bone ossification.
Radiographs showed complete aplasia of the clavicles bilaterally, decreased ossification of the pubic bones, and shortened 11th and absent 12th ribs.

At 6 weeks of age he required a tracheostomy for increasing airway obstruction due to micrognathia and glossoptosis, and at 3 months of age tracheomalacia with persistent respiratory distress required treatment with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).
A Nissen fundoplication was done and a gastrostomy tube was inserted for treatment of gastroesophageal reflux and aspiration of oral feedings.

His respiratory status gradually improved, allowing decannulation at age 18 months, but he has continued to have poor oral motor skills and requires nutritional supplementation by gastrostomy tube at age 3Â½ years.
His growth parameters are normal, with weight in the 25th percentile, and height and head circumference in the 50th percentiles.
Developmental milestones have been normal, and at age 3 years normal language and cognitive development have been documented.
A 3D CT scan at age 3 years demonstrated widened sutures and Wormian bones in the position of the right parietal bone (Fig. 1).
